replication_study.hypothesis: In country-year data from GEM, a one standard deviation decrease in the country’s median age (computed for ages 20–64) is associated with an increase in the entrepreneurship rate (share owning/managing a business up to 42 months old and paying wages), around 2.5 percentage points circa 2010; formally, the entrepreneurship rate is negatively associated with median age.

data_plan.source_type: Cross-national survey aggregates from the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM) with population demographics from the U.S. Census Bureau IDB (as per original paper).
data_plan.wave_or_subset: Country-year observations spanning 2001–2016 in this file; primary replication focuses on 2001–2010 with a cross-section highlight for 2010.
data_plan.sample_size: 789 country-year rows; 786 non-missing for median_age; 2010 cross-section includes multiple countries (n_countries_2010 computed in script).
data_plan.access_details: Data file provided locally in the replication package. For execution, place replication_data_mkk9.csv at /app/data/replication_data_mkk9.csv.

qualification.explanation: This dataset contains country-year entrepreneurship rates consistent with GEM’s early-stage business definition and the median age (20–64) measure from IDB. It is directly suitable to replicate the country-year regressions relating entrepreneurship rates to median age and to compute the 1 SD effect in 2010.
qualification.similarity_to_original: The original paper (original_paper.pdf; summarized in post_registration.json) uses GEM country-year data (2001–2010) with entrepreneurship defined as owning/managing a business <42 months old and paying wages, and median age computed using IDB for ages 20–64. The provided data dictionary (liang_mkk9_dictionary.tsv) confirms entrepreneurship is constructed from GEM’s BABYBUSO item and median_age is computed for ages 20–64 from IDB. The post_registration.json cites the same concept and period (GEM 2001–2010).
qualification.deviation_from_original: The provided dataset includes years beyond 2010 (up to 2016 per get_dataset_description and the dictionary), whereas the original focal analysis and headline claim emphasize the 2010 cross-section and 2001–2010 panel (post_registration.json, original_paper.pdf summary). Our panel analyses restrict to 2001–2010 to match the original, but the file’s extended coverage represents a larger sample than used in the original. Some macro controls used in the original (GDP per capita, startup costs, etc.) are not present in this replication file; thus, the core replication here targets the reduced-form specification with median age plus fixed effects and weights, focusing on the focal median-age effect, not all robustness controls.

data_plan.notes: Variables: entrepreneurship (proportion), median_age (20–64), year, country, cy_cell (respondent count 20–64), phone_code, and country_year ID. The entrepreneurship measure appears to be based on ages 20–64 (per dictionary). Observations are to be weighted by cy_cell (per Table 2 note cited in the dictionary). The 2010 mean entrepreneurship rate and SD of median age are computed from the dataset and used to construct scaled effects comparable to the paper’s 2.5 percentage points statement.

steps: Drop rows with missing entrepreneurship, median_age, year, country, or cy_cell.
Compute 2010 cross-section SD of median_age and mean entrepreneurship for interpretability.
Estimate weighted least squares (weights=cy_cell) regression for 2010 cross-section: entrepreneurship ~ median_age; robust HC1 SE.
Estimate panel WLS for 2001–2010: entrepreneurship ~ median_age + year fixed effects; cluster SE by country.
Estimate panel WLS for 2001–2010: entrepreneurship ~ median_age + country FE + year FE; cluster SE by country.
For each model, compute the effect of a one SD decrease in 2010 median age: −beta_median_age × SD_2010(median_age), with SE and 95% CI; convert to percentage points.
planned_method.models: Weighted least squares (WLS) with cy_cell weights. Cross-section 2010 WLS with robust HC1 SE; panel (2001–2010) WLS with year FE and with country+year FE, standard errors clustered by country.
planned_method.outcome_variable: entrepreneurship (proportion owning/managing a business up to 42 months old and paying wages, GEM-based)
planned_method.control_variables: Year fixed effects; Country fixed effects (in one panel spec). Macro controls from the original paper are not included due to absence in provided dataset.

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Coefficient on median_age in WLS regressions; scaled effect for 1 SD decrease in 2010 median_age expressed in percentage points
planned_estimation_and_test.test: t-tests for the median_age coefficient; robust HC1 in cross-section; cluster-robust by country in panel

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion for rows missing entrepreneurship, median_age, year, country, or cy_cell.
planned_method.multiple_testing_policy: Not applicable (single focal outcome and parameter).
planned_method.inference_criteria: Two-sided tests; significance at 5%; direction expected negative coefficient on median_age; scaled effect magnitude compared against 2.5 percentage points benchmark.

files.replicate_mkk9.py: Entrypoint Python script. Reads /app/data/replication_data_mkk9.csv, runs WLS regressions for the 2010 cross-section and 2001–2010 panels with appropriate weights and robust/clustered SEs, computes one-SD decrease effect for median age using 2010 SD, outputs JSON summaries to /app/data.

codebase.notes: All IO paths under /app/data. Ensure replication_data_mkk9.csv is copied to /app/data before running. No non-Python scripts required; no external macro data needed for the focal claim replication.

instructions: Place replication_data_mkk9.csv into ./data so it is available at /app/data/replication_data_mkk9.csv inside the container.
Inspect outputs: /app/data/replication_summary_mkk9.json and /app/data/replication_results_mkk9.json for coefficients, p-values, and scaled effects (percentage points).
comparison_metrics: Sign and significance of median_age coefficient (expect negative, significant).

Magnitude of one SD decrease effect on entrepreneurship in 2010 cross-section expressed in percentage points; compare to 2.5 pp reported (initial_details.txt; original_paper.pdf and post_registration.json).
Relative to mean entrepreneurship in 2010 (percentage of mean), qualitatively assess proximity to 40% of mean (~0.061 around 2010 per original).
